title: Developing the automatic measurement of surface condition on local roads
segmentation: I notice that this site of this morning session is seems like surface condition measurement.
In particular cracking.
So I'm actually not going to talk about cracking this presentation.
Sorry about that.
So anyone who doesn't want to leave this move on at the back, but I'm sure it's going to be interesting.
Anyway, thank you for turning up 9:00 o'clock.
It's 8:00 o'clock for me, and I'm not an early riser, so I'll do my best.

This presentation is called the development of automatic Measurement certification on local roads, and it's concentrating on the work that we've been undertaking TRL for the UK Department for Transport in transferring our.
High speed surveys from our trunk Rd network which is our motorways onto our local minor Rd network which presents a more of a challenge to the measurement of condition.
The automatic measurement of condition.
I think I briefly touched on this yesterday.

In the UK we have a national condition survey called tracks on the Trunk Rd network which covers 40,000 kilometers of the network each year that was expanded in 2003 to local roads and has gradually grown that number.
There is actually incorrect.
We now do $100,000 of these surveys each year in the UK using automatic fully automatic measurement systems.
This system is used lasers to measure longitudinal and transverse profile.
Imaging to measure cracking, which is processed automatically and the measurement geometry as well, which we.
It's not heavily used in in the UK with link to our texture measurements to help with assessment of schemes and friction.
The surveys carried out and end result specification, which is defined centrally and contractors are submit their systems for accreditation testing against that.
Specification currently we have I think that says there 8 systems.
In the UK accredited.
The there are.
Two of these errands errands that called in America for some reason.
The road assessment vehicle Rav Run by a company called WDM who work out of Bristol in the UK and the Ramboll based system run by Jacobs Engineering.
Each of them is accredited and they have an annual RE accreditation process.
We also have two vehicles which we use for reference.
Harris Warren Harris two which would develop by Tyrrell and we do some collecting reference data and assessing quality assurance and for the research program.
Trunk Rd Network looks somewhat like this motorways three Lane Mason, Georgia Major Lazer, three lanes with hard shoulder.

We are now expanding our use of these roads to take to have use of the hard shoulder as well, so we have a number of schemes, typically around Birmingham in the center of England where there is traffic control to enable users to drive down the hard shoulder when the traffic is heavy.
He's presenting new challenges to our measurement systems, talking to work out what those hard shoulders are made of, and what Sir condition there in.
That's a separate story.
Our local roads look more like this in rural areas.
This is sort of a typical rural.
A stroke B road and this is more like a rural city.
Road and we are covering all of these roads now each each year.
With these automated surveys we do these roads on the basis of about 25% a year to rolling survey.
Arobin rates look a bit like this.
Usually they're packed with traffic.
I don't know when they manage to take this photograph and they have a range of conditions.
Often quite poor profile and cracking and pressure to difficulty to access them for surveyors with parked cars and things like that.
What do we do the data?
For local use the individual parameters that the survey contractor measures are reported over 10 meter lengths and that things like writing ride quality.
Texture, depth and area of cracking and and you.
That data combination of both premises and also is used to target length.
The combination of the road condition indicated data is used to determine what proportion of the network is in poor condition and that is just thresholded against 3 levels.
Give you red, green and Amber percentage of condition, which is this graph here down here.
Which says that if you've got a regional network, you'll have about 5% of it in poor condition and authorities all have to report that to the government protest nationally.
A good level to have would be about 5% and there's 150 of those reported each year.
Now when we started moving the survey onto the local Rd network, the authorities came.
Back and said, well, why do we want this survey?

We're quite happy with our vision condition surveys were currently carrying out and you're going to love this survey down our throats and there was an aspect of that in the UK because we wanted a national measure of condition and the government said you will use these surveys.
It is compulsory but they are paid for locali.

So although the government says you will carry out condition surveys the contract, they got, the local authorities have to pay out of their own funds to Commission survey contractors to undertake the surveys.
And there was an idea that we don't provide a bit more incentive so that they could make good use of this data.
So we said we will undertake a research program to try and improve the use of the data and this was targeted in three areas.
It was the use of ride quality ride quality which is an area that local authorities are totally UN used to.
We don't like all these, not a parameter that local engineers have any experience with.

The measurement of surface deterioration at the edge of the road, which is a particular defect on local roads, where the haunches at the edge of the road collapse and engineers will have a good idea about what that defects are present at the edge of the road.
So it's quite a strong driver for maintenance and the use of data or text dated to assess general surf situation.
I'm not going to go into that 'cause there was a bit of discussion about yesterday.
So these two parameters.

Now, the work that we've done is concentrated on the use of shape data, and when I say shape data, I mean the measurements that are provided by the laser systems, the traffic speed and this is sort of a standard output for much traffic speed services.
You've got a nice good quality Patch.

It's just been successfully late as you can see, and it left a rather horrible hole in the road and the profile systems are quite capable of being able to detect that, but you want to have good systems to automatically tell you that they're there and quantify the condition, and it's these sort of things that we use in the shape data for.
SO22 parts of shape measurements for local roses.

Ride Quality, which is a standard measure on trunk roads, but as I said before, is not a lot of experience in this area for local engineers, and we went and asked them about that and they said what do we do with ride quality?
Can you convince us that we should be using this and we said well yes it is a good, reliable indicator of users of users concern.
It will identify locations where users are happy and they wanted to be convinced of that.
But they also said that one of the real problems is the fact that they get holes appearing in the roads that they want to target.
These causing bumps so we went to battery search program to see if we could use generate some automatic measures to identify these features.

Now some of this was a little bit of reinventing the wheel because there's some historical knowledge about the way that ride quality effects users, but we thought we would see if we could target these measures on local roads, and to do that, we instrumented a number of vehicles with this equipment here.
Down here, which is a standard, it's a standard canvas reader, can fit into most.
Modern cars have camp serial buses on them to transfer information about the vehicle, such as the activity of the suspension system, the drivetrain and you can log it in real time.

Fact, we also at this in a separate research program related that data to the right quality as well, which is quite interested but not part of this presentation and a has analog inputs which enables the user to text to say what they thought their thoughts on the condition of the road was, and that's what the dial is for.
They usually just drove along and so you drove along.
And the user sat in the passenger seat and they turn the dial to say what the condition was.
They also had a push button.
And we tell them when they're really wound up by the quality of the ride to press it.
And then we took that and related to the profile data.
Now we used car surveys and motorbike service.
We actually also equipped to push bike with this.
This system which was very entertaining to use.
In fact, the person who I asked to do it did leave Tyrrell very shortly after doing it.
I think he thought his life expectancy was getting a bit low.
Being asked to do this work, but it did give in for useful information.
The data is reported to reference the GPS and which related it to the profile data collected with this scanner device.
Now we did a number of assessments of this data.
And found it on the local roads.

The wavelengths of interest were centered around one to five meters, and that was the areas where the users reported poor ride quality, so they hire Dyer values tends to be associated with places where the ride the profile had features in the range of five, one to five meters, and we did a number of comparisons between that data and standard ride measures that are used in the world today, like IRRI, the French coefficient, planetis, waveband energies, standard deviations.
And our current measures that we use in the UK, which is the moving average profile variance and we also looked at a new new measurement of variance which you called enhance variance.
And this is basically looking at the deviation of the profile from a filtered profile data filtered at wavelengths centered on 310 and 30 meters.
Now we combined all these profile all those parameters up and try to say which one would be the one that would be best related to what the dial said and actually.
Out of interest, the there wasn't very strong differences in any of these parameters.
They all gave you about the same correlation with what the users were giving you.
The one that we found to be closest actually was the one that we are currently using, which is the enhanced variance measure and that was closely followed by RI.
But the statistical significance probably wasn't much, but it gave us little justification to move over to our in the UK, and that's one of the reasons we're still not using it.
Interesting things about IR.

I of course for interview know about it is that YRI response across the broader wavelength range, whereas felt focused measurements like variance and the French measured methods don't say, although YRI covers a broad range of wavelengths.
The various measure doesn't.
Say.
We have you moved.
The movement of in use to the application of enhanced variance in the UK for measuring general ride quality.
But actually for our users our engineers, they're not really that interested in this general quality.

They really interested in where their users are very annoyed by the quality of the ride, and for that we use the push button and we ask these people to press the button when the measurement when the road profile really annoyed them.
And, um.
Fish.
Try to relate that with the data that the metric system have given us and what we were finding was.
So is that the locations where users press the.
Button.
Here.

Didn't necessarily relate to where the ride quality measures the variance measure or the YRI measure any of them were responding, which was saying that you had the ride quality issues, which are measures aren't responding to.
If I just go back.
Up and what we noticed was that those most of those are in a very short wavelength range, which is quite obvious because bumps that give rise to sharp jolting boat movements inside a vehicle are.
Associated with holes in the pavement and those aren't focused.
Targeted well by feature by processing systems which look over long lengths and say what you need to do is to target a method to identify those holes.
And that's what we've also been doing in our mission of shape.
UK.
And to do that, we developed a new parameter.
A new parameter which we called the bump measure because none of our customers knew what the central difference method was about.
Anne.
Is based on looking at the rate of change of profile.
It's looking at the 1st and 2nd derivatives of the profile longer short length.

And that system can be used to successfully develop identify these holes that appear in the payment and so you can use the longer feature detection with wavelength measures like variance or I if that's your preference to identify roughness but use these special measures to identify holes.
And these are the places where the users really complain, and these bumps are the features that appear on local roads and not necessarily on trunk roads because the trade network.
If you have holes like this appearing in it.
They have a requirement to maintain within 24 hours anyway, so our routine visual surveys picking up, but our local Rd surveys don't do that.
So we implemented that on our local Rd network and it found that it reported 84.

If the button presses that our users reported, but there was a potential higher number of false positives in that it reports locations where the users didn't press the bottom, but when we went and looked at those sites and looked at the profile data as well, it was associated with holes in the pavement.
So it might be that for several of the car just hadn't driven over them in the user survey or that they weren't severe enough for course used to press the button.
But we're still features that you would want to know about.
And we went and took that out on the network and tested on our trunk roads and went and looked at the locations where the users press the buttons, which is these blue dots.
This is in the southeast of England and found that.
It also reported quite a high proportion of the bumps that present present on that network.
In fact, as I said before, the.
These features shouldn't appear on that Rd network.

These features that give rise to Sevilla, Sevilla, issues with users, and we went and spoke to our local Highways Agency engine area in the region that we tested and he went out with his crew and looked at these locations and came back and said yes, you're right, these are all category one defects, which are defects that should be picked up during our day-to-day measurement runs routine.
We called the RMS and we should fix them, but we haven't.
And was rather embarrassed and said one of the issues with the measure like this is that the government can no longer be in denial.
So actually you have to be quite careful when you implement them because you've got a defect system which can measure features which may be safety related.
And yet you might not be able to treat them, so it's a bit of a lesson in that the technology is ending up giving you stuff that maybe you didn't really want to know about, but it can do it.
So why not use it?
A.
The second present part of this presentation is looking at the other key defects that we.
Our local engineers will consultation said they're interested in which was the deterioration of the edge of local roads.
Alot of the road network in the UK, the local Rd network is what is involved in that it started off as a car track built in the 1900s.
Early 1900s started being used for car vehicle traffic and gradually got increased in use and that Rd was never originally wide enough for the vehicles to drive down.
The local authority is responsible to it would have launched.
It would have widened it and eventually it's suitable for motor vehicles, but the traffic gets it in with increasing level of traffic.

In heavy vehicles the edge of the road is always subject to a lot of wear and what you want is a good way of detecting whether that wears appearing and quantifying it on two of the most serious of ways that it appears is potholes in the edge, which is the actual edge of the road collapsing.
And overriding the verge, which is where trucks drive over the road verge and wear it away and the result of that is stepping.
And both of these are safety.
Defects are particularly important for cyclists, 'cause when you fall down the steps you for feedback and the truck followed you runs you over, which isn't very nice.
Profile data is very good for this because profile systems on local roads tend to have the capability to measure outside the width of the vehicle.
Now standard profile system used in the UK will measure between 3 1/2 and 4 meters with from a 2.2 meters survey vehicle.
So it's measuring outside of its width by about up to a meter for seven.
One of the one of the vehicles we currently have.
And what we've been looking at is whether the shape of the profile down the road can tell you about the.
Um?
The deterioration at the road edge.
And this is based on the premise of identifying the road edge.
And then looking at a strip of the edge and quantifying the deterioration that's within it.
And we have developed three parameters to define that following the detection of the road edge, which is a simple.
Actually it's quite complicated and I'm not going to go into it.
Method of looking features in the profile at the edge.
We then define a strip and look at roughness within it, which is a localized variance measure.
We look at stepping at the edge, which is what is the changing profile at the edge of the road at this step at this at this?
Line here.
And we look at what is the difference between the roughness in this part of the road and the roughness in this part of the road?
So it's looking at roughness across the pavement.
And those three things combined can tell you whether the edge of the road is collapsing or is in poor condition.
And that's sort of a visual visual, more clear, hopefully.
Sharing that looking at an edge strip, looking at stepping at the edge and looking at the difference of in evenness across the road, and as you can see here this part, the road is sound.
Whereas the edge of the road is in poor condition.
And this is their example.
Transverse and evenness edge roughness.
Here, looking at the reference of the near the edge of the road and stepping where the edge of the road is actually collapsed.
And we have some quite good success with applying this system in the UK.

It's now being moved out onto the these under the scanner survey for the last year and and we're getting good feedback from engineers that it does give you good agreement with where the local authorities manual surveys said that there was edge deterioration.
This is just showing an example over a few kilometres, something that's 100 and something kilometres of data.
The data is being averaged over a reasonably long length because this isn't this is a network measure, so it's identifying lengths of the network.
Where you need to go and do more investigation and it's giving quite good agreement.

As you can see in these areas between where the manual survey of course visual inspection gave edge deterioration and where are fully automatic inspection, go vegetarian, there's no manual intervention with this data.
The measures are a bit complicated, so that we've we've combined them into an indicator based on the same logic as we use on the rest of our parameters.
So whereas when we survey the network of their standard conditions, we look for writing and roughness and texture, we combine those together.
We get an indicator that says that length is in poor condition.
We say right now that length has poor edge condition, and we haven't indicated for that.
Agent aeration indicator.
Tell you once again highlight lengths.
And has not quite so good way of presenting it.
But it does have good agreement with the reference and maybe that's a better way with on a network level what proportion of our network.
Does the edge condition indicator tell us is poor and what proportion of our network did our course visual inspection tell you were poor when splitting it by AB&C Rhodes?
Now as we would expect, the proportion of the network having poor edge condition increases proportionately with reducing classification.
With this data set was a bit of an anomaly because our data set for testing had a very short length of unclassified roads in it.
These are really minor roads, and it's the network over which we haven't introduced automated surveys yet.
We are considering introducing these and this adds another 200,000 kilometres of our network.
For these automated condition systems, which is going to be a challenge.
This indicates is now being implemented.
Nationwide in the UK.
So just to conclude.
When are applying surveys in the UK over 100 / 100,000 kilometres a year, and in particular a large proportion of these local roads allow our trunk.
Rd Network only represents about thirty 40,000 kilometres.
It means that previous developments have happened which have all been focused on major roads.
Really need to move their focus to local roads, because that is actually a bigger length, and in fact the contract is.
It's a bigger market and they're running around trying to get surveys out of you.
Once you move into that market.
Contract is seeing that 200,000 Euro 200,000 kilometre potential of unclassified roads will get very excited.

But you do need to make sure that you're collecting the right sort of data at the right locations and at the right time, and what you don't want to do is just roll out a survey just because you can measure it.
So because of that, we've done a research program to try and develop parameters focused at those roads, and we have therefore delivered provide quality measures focused on the users perception.
And measures of HCT reation all based on profile measurements that's me finished.
Thank you.
